t: Job 15
Eliphaz Says Job Presumes Much
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite responded,
“Should*pn a wise man answer with windy knowledge And*ln fill himself with the east wind?
Should*ln he argue with useless talk, Or*ln with words which are not profitable?
Indeed,*ln you do away with reverence And*ln hinder meditation before God.
For*ln your guilt teaches your mouth, And*ln you choose the language of the crafty.
Your*ln own mouth condemns you, and not I; And*ln your own lips testify against you.
“Were*ln you the first man to be born, Or*ln were you brought forth before the hills?
Do*ln you hear the secret counsel of God, And*ln limit wisdom to yourself?
What*ln do you know that we do not know? What*iln do you understand that we do not?
Both*ln the gray-haired and the aged are among us, Older*ln than your father.
Are*ln the consolations of God too small for you, Even*ln the word spoken*i gently with you?
Why*ln does your heart carry you away? And*ln why do your eyes flash,
That*ln you should turn your spirit against God And*ln allow such*i words to go out of your mouth?
What*ln is man, that he should be pure, Or*ln he who is born of a woman, that he should be righteous?
Behold,*ln He puts no trust in His holy ones, And*ln the heavens are not pure in His sight;
How*ln much less one who is detestable and corrupt, Man,*ln who drinks iniquity like water!
What Eliphaz Has Seen of Life
“I*pn will tell you, listen to me; And*ln what I have seen I will also declare;
What*ln wise men have told, And*ln have not concealed from their fathers,
To*ln whom alone the land was given, And*ln no alien passed among them.
The*ln wicked man writhes in pain all his*i days, And*ln numbered are the years stored up for the ruthless.
Sounds*ln of terror are in his ears; While*ln at peace the destroyer comes upon him.
He*ln does not believe that he will return from darkness, And*ln he is destined for the sword.
He*ln wanders about for food, saying, ‘Where is it?’ He*ln knows that a day of darkness is at hand.
Distress*ln and anguish terrify him, They*ln overpower him like a king ready for the attack,
Because*ln he has stretched out his hand against God And*ln conducts himself arrogantly against the Almighty.
He*ln rushes headlong at Him With*ln his massive shield.
For*ln he has covered his face with his fat And*ln made his thighs heavy with flesh.
He*ln has lived in desolate cities, In*ln houses no one would inhabit, Which*ln are destined to become ruins.
He*ln will not become rich, nor will his wealth endure; And*ln his grain will not bend down to the ground.
He*ln will not escape from darkness; The*ln flame will wither his shoots, And*ln by the breath of His mouth he will go away.
Let*ln him not trust in emptiness, deceiving himself; For*ln emptiness will be his reward.
It*ln will be accomplished before his time, And*ln his palm branch will not be green.
He*ln will drop off his unripe grape like the vine, And*ln will cast off his flower like the olive tree.
For*ln the company of the godless is barren, And*ln fire consumes the tents of the corrupt.
They*ln conceive mischief and bring forth iniquity, And*ln their mind prepares deception.”
